elements.content: A Zr metal–organic framework (MOF) 1-CoCl3 has been synthesized by solvothermal reaction of ZrCl4 with a carboxylic acid-functionalized CoIII-PNNNP pincer complex H4(L-CoCl3) ([L-CoCl3]4– = [(2,6-(NHPAr2)2C6H3)­CoCl3]4–, Ar = p-C6H4CO2 –). The structure of 1-CoCl3 has been determined by X-ray powder diffraction and exhibits a csq topology that differs from previously reported ftw-net Zr MOFs assembled from related PdII- and PtII-PNNNP pincer complexes. The Co-PNNNP pincer species readily demetallate upon reduction of CoIII to CoII, allowing for transmetalation with late second and third row transition metals in both the homogeneous complex and 1-CoCl3 . Reaction of 1-CoCl3 with [Rh­(nbd)­Cl]2 (nbd = 2,5-nobornadiene) results in complete Rh/Co metal exchange at the supported diphosphine pincer complexes to generate 1-RhCl, which has been inaccessible by direct solvothermal synthesis. Treating 1-CoCl3 with PtCl2(SMe2)2 in the presence of the mild reductant NEt3 resulted in nearly complete Co substitution by Pt. In addition, a mixed metal pincer MOF, 1-PtRh, was generated by sequential substitution of Co with Pt followed by Rh.

The structure of 1-CoCl3  has been determined by X-ray powder diffraction and exhibits a csq topology that differs from previously reported ftw-net Zr MOFs assembled from related PdII- and PtII-PNNNP pincer complexes. elements.content: A Zr MOF containing CoIII-PNNNP pincer metallolinkers has been synthesized and structurally characterized. Postsynthetic metal exchange allows the pincer-supported CoCl3 group to be replaced by RhCl and PtCl fragments.
elements.clean_text: A Zr MOF containing CoIII-PNNNP pincer metallolinkers has been synthesized and structurally characterized. Postsynthetic metal exchange allows the pincer-supported CoCl3 group to be replaced by RhCl and PtCl fragments.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have emerged as a versatile class of porous materials with potential applications in areas such as gas storage and separation, heterogeneous catalysis, drug delivery, and electronic devices. Much of the interest in MOFs stems from their well-defined porous structures and ability to accommodate a wide range of chemical functionalities at both the inorganic and organic building units. However, reactive functional groups are often challenging to incorporate via de novo synthesis, prompting the development of a wide variety of postsynthetic modification strategies. Among these, postsynthetic metal exchange (PSME) at either the metal nodes or organic linkers has become a valuable strategy for accessing materials that cannot be obtained by direct solvothermal assembly. Significant progress toward understanding PSME at the metal nodes of MOFs, has led to the development of new materials with enhanced performance in gas separation processes, heterogeneous catalysis, and other applications. However, PSME at organometallic linker groups has been explored to a lesser extent, and reported examples have generally been limited to MOFs containing metallosalen and metalloporphyrins struts. For example, Shultz et al. reported the demetalation of Mn from a metallosalen-based MOF using H2O2 as the demetalating reagent. The resulting material could be remetalated with a variety of divalent transition metal cations, and its catalytic activity for enantioselective epoxidation restored. Ma and co-workers demonstrated that Cd2+ weakly bound at the porphyrin-based linkers of MMPF-5 could be readily exchanged for Co2+, yielding a material that performed well for catalytic epoxidation of trans-stilbene. More recently, Jiang et al. have reported PSME of Cd for first row transition metals at both the metal nodes and porphyrin linkers of a chiral porphyrin−salen MOF. The exchange could be carried out in a single crystal to single crystal transformation, and the Co2+-exchanged analogue catalyzed asymmetric cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have emerged as a versatile class of porous materials with potential applications in areas such as gas storage and separation, heterogeneous catalysis, drug delivery, and electronic devices. Much of the interest in MOFs stems from their well-defined porous structures and ability to accommodate a wide range of chemical functionalities at both the inorganic and organic building units. However, reactive functional groups are often challenging to incorporate via de novo synthesis, prompting the development of a wide variety of postsynthetic modification strategies. Among these, postsynthetic metal exchange (PSME) at either the metal nodes or organic linkers has become a valuable strategy for accessing materials that cannot be obtained by direct solvothermal assembly. Significant progress toward understanding PSME at the metal nodes of MOFs, has led to the development of new materials with enhanced performance in gas separation processes, heterogeneous catalysis, and other applications. However, PSME at organometallic linker groups has been explored to a lesser extent, and reported examples have generally been limited to MOFs containing metallosalen and metalloporphyrins struts. For example, Shultz et al. reported the demetalation of Mn from a metallosalen-based MOF using H2O2 as the demetalating reagent. The resulting material could be remetalated with a variety of divalent transition metal cations, and its catalytic activity for enantioselective epoxidation restored. Ma and co-workers demonstrated that Cd2+ weakly bound at the porphyrin-based linkers of MMPF-5 could be readily exchanged for Co2+, yielding a material that performed well for catalytic epoxidation of trans-stilbene. More recently, Jiang et al. have reported PSME of Cd for first row transition metals at both the metal nodes and porphyrin linkers of a chiral porphyrin-salen MOF. The exchange could be carried out in a single crystal to single crystal transformation, and the Co2+-exchanged analogue catalyzed asymmetric cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides.

elements.content: Recently, we and others have been interested in the synthesis and reactivity of MOFs constructed from pincer complexes. In particular, diphosphine pincer ligands have become ubiquitous in homogeneous catalysis owing to their versatility and ability to support a wide range of late transition metals. The combination of the chelating pincer framework and strong phosphine donor groups confers a high degree of stability that makes the pincer complexes resistant to demetalation and often allows them to withstand high temperatures and harsh catalytic conditions. Consequently, reported examples of metal exchange reactions with pincer ligand scaffolds are rare and have been limited to a few Zr and Ag complexes. To the best of our knowledge, there are no reported examples of transition metal exchange reactions with diphosphine pincer complexes. Herein we report the direct solvothermal synthesis of a Zr MOF, 1-CoCl3 , constructed from CoIII-PNNNP pincer metallolinkers. Both the MOF and the homogeneous analogue of the linker undergo Co demetalation under reducing conditions and transmetalation with RhI and PtII. Furthermore, a multimetallic MOF, 1-RhPt, can be generated through sequential substitution of Co with Pt followed by Rh.

Herein we report the direct solvothermal synthesis of a Zr MOF, 1-CoCl3 , constructed from CoIII-PNNNP pincer metallolinkers. elements.content: The CoIII-PNNNP pincer complexes tBu4(L-CoCl3) and H4(L-CoCl3) were synthesized as shown in and have been characterized by multinuclear NMR spectroscopy and elemental analysis (Figures S1–S6). A solution of H4(L-CoCl3) and ZrCl4 in 4/1/1 (v/v/v) dimethylformamide (DMF)/HOAc/HCl (concentrated aqueous) was sealed in a 20 mL vial and heated at 80 °C for 16 h, resulting in formation of 1-CoCl3 as an orange microcrystalline powder. The structure of 1-CoCl3 has been determined from synchrotron X-ray powder diffraction (SXPD) data (). Indexing provided a hexagonal unit cell (a = 32.42 Å, c = 15.41 Å) with no systematic absences that would indicate the presence of screw axes or glide planes. An initial structure model was constructed with P6/mmm space group symmetry based on the positions of the heavy atoms located using a charge flipping algorithm. The model indicated that the structure of 1-CoCl3 is similar to that of csq-net Zr MOFs containing 8-connected Zr6 clusters ([(Zr6O4(OH)4(OAc)4]8+, OAc = CH3CO2 –, c) and tetratopic metalloporphyrin- or pyrene-based linkers.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Characterization of 1-CoCl3  

The CoIII-PNNNP pincer complexes tBu4(L-CoCl3) and H4(L-CoCl3) were synthesized as shown in  and have been characterized by multinuclear NMR spectroscopy and elemental analysis (Figures S1-S6). A solution of H4(L-CoCl3) and ZrCl4 in 4/1/1 (v/v/v) dimethylformamide (DMF)/HOAc/HCl (concentrated aqueous) was sealed in a 20 mL vial and heated at 80 °C for 16 h, resulting in formation of 1-CoCl3  as an orange microcrystalline powder. The structure of 1-CoCl3  has been determined from synchrotron X-ray powder diffraction (SXPD) data (). Indexing provided a hexagonal unit cell (a = 32.42 Å, c = 15.41 Å) with no systematic absences that would indicate the presence of screw axes or glide planes. An initial structure model was constructed with P6/mmm space group symmetry based on the positions of the heavy atoms located using a charge flipping algorithm. The model indicated that the structure of 1-CoCl3  is similar to that of csq-net Zr MOFs containing 8-connected Zr6 clusters ([(Zr6O4(OH)4(OAc)4]8+, OAc = CH3CO2 -, c) and tetratopic metalloporphyrin- or pyrene-based linkers.

elements.content:
Reagents: (i) [CoCl2(C5H5N)4]­Cl, CH2Cl2, rt, 1 h; (ii) [(n-C4H9)4N]­Cl, CH2Cl2, 30 °C, 16 h; (iii) CF3CO2H, CH2Cl2, rt, 16 h; (iv) ZrCl4 (3 equiv), DMF/AcOH/HCl (aqueous), 80 °C, 16 h.

Rietveld refinements using simulated annealing with the metal cluster and linker as rigid bodies were carried out in the P6 space group for six structure permutations arising from three possible orientations of the Zr6 clusters and two possible orientations of the [L-CoCl3]4– linkers (Figure S7). A structural arrangement with the C4 axis of the Zr6 clusters aligned perpendicular to the c axis and the central arene group of the [L-CoCl3]4– pincer complexes perpendicular to the ab plane provided the best fit to the data (b). The space group symmetry was subsequently increased from P6 to P6/mmm while maintaining the refinement residuals. When allowed to refine freely, the occupancy of the [L-CoCl3]4– rigid body converged to 47% (R wp = 10.563), which corresponds to a linker/Zr6 cluster ratio of 0.94:1. The low refined occupancy of the [L-CoCl3]4– linker reflects a significant deviation from the anticipated framework formula of Zr6O4(OH)4(OAc)4(L-CoCl3)2 and points to missing-linker defects. The presence of these defects has been corroborated by spectroscopic characterization and elemental analysis (vide infra). The final structure of 1-CoCl3 is best described by a xly net with the phosphine groups of [L-CoCl3]4– as 3-c branch points. It contains trigonal and hexagonal channels along the c-axis that have maximum diameters of ∼10 and ∼15 Å, respectively, with the CoCl3 groups of the [L-CoCl3]4– pincers facing inward to the smaller trigonal channels.

elements.content: Notably, the structure of 1-CoCl3 differs from that of an isostructural series of Zr MOFs assembled from Pd and Pt diphosphine pincer complexes that we have recently reported. 2-PdX, 3-PdX, and 3-PtX adopt the cubic framework structure shown in that can be described by a ftw net. The framework topology of Zr MOFs containing other tetratopic linkers has been shown to depend on the intramolecular torsion angles maintained between the linker core and benzoate arms. In the case of 1-CoCl3 , the axial ligands of the pseudo-octahedral CoIII center are more likely to inhibit rotation of the benzoate groups than the square planar Pd and Pt centers in 2-PdX, 3-PdX, and 3-PtX. Thus, we attribute the difference in observed topologies of the Zr pincer MOFs to the coordination environment of the pincer-supported metal center and its impact on the freedom of rotation of the benzoate groups.

The framework topology of Zr MOFs containing other tetratopic linkers has been shown to depend on the intramolecular torsion angles maintained between the linker core and benzoate arms. In the case of 1-CoCl3 , the axial ligands of the pseudo-octahedral CoIII center are more likely to inhibit rotation of the benzoate groups than the square planar Pd and Pt centers in 2-PdX, 3-PdX, and 3-PtX. Thus, we attribute the difference in observed topologies of the Zr pincer MOFs to the coordination environment of the pincer-supported metal center and its impact on the freedom of rotation of the benzoate groups.

elements.content: NMR spectroscopic characterization and elemental analysis of 1-CoCl3 are consistent with the framework structure determined from the SXPD data and provide further insight into the composition. The solid-state 31P NMR spectrum of 1-CoCl3 reveals two major resonances centered at 62 and 70 ppm (). These signals appear at a chemical shift similar to the resonance observed for H4(L-CoCl3) in solution (67.3 ppm, Figure S5), supporting the presence of similar CoIII pincer species in the MOF. Minor signals observed in the 15–30 ppm region are consistent with the presence of a small amount of oxidized phosphine species arising from decomposition of the PNNNP pincer linkers. However, quantitative analysis of the spectrum was hampered by fast T2 relaxation that likely arises from a small amount of paramagnetic CoII species present in the sample (vide infra). The solution state 31P NMR spectrum measured for an acid-digested (CF3CO2H/C6D6, 3/1, v/v) sample of 1-CoCl3 exhibits a major signal at 67.6 ppm (∼86%) and minor one at 67.2 ppm (∼14%) (Figure S11). The 31P NMR spectrum of H4(L-CoCl3) shows similar speciation in the same solvent mixture, suggesting that the acid-digestion conditions induce Co–Cl solvolysis. Consequently, the acid-digested 31P NMR data do not provide direct insight into the speciation of the CoIII-PNNNP linkers present in the MOF. We surmise that the two distinct signals observed in the solid-state 31P NMR spectrum of 1-CoCl3 arise from a mixture of CoIIICl3 and CoIIICl2(X) pincer species, but the identity of the putative X ligand has not been firmly established.

elements.content: The 1H NMR spectrum of an acid-digested sample of as-synthesized 1-CoCl3 displays all signals expected for H4(L-CoCl3) as well as resonances corresponding to HOAc, HCO2H, and [Me2NH2]+ (Figure S12). While the HOAc should result from digestion of [Zr6O4(OH)4(OAc)4]8+ SBUs, the latter species seem to arise from pore-occluding guests (see the Supporting Information for details). Indeed, the impurities responsible for the appearance of HCO2H, and [Me2NH2]+ could be removed by soaking the MOF in MeOH over a period of 24 h to generate 1-CoCl3(MeOH) (Figure S16). This washing procedure does not affect the bulk crystallinity of the MOF but does exacerbate decomposition of the pincer complex as observed from the solid-state 31P NMR spectrum (). Moreover, the two distinct 31P NMR resonances that were present in the solid-state spectrum of 1-CoCl3 merge into a broad signal centered at 65 ppm in 1-CoCl3(MeOH). Efforts to remove the impurities with other solvents such as acetone, DMF, or THF were unsuccessful.

While the HOAc should result from digestion of [Zr6O4(OH)4(OAc)4]8+ SBUs, the latter species seem to arise from pore-occluding guests (see the Supporting Information for details). Indeed, the impurities responsible for the appearance of HCO2H, and [Me2NH2]+ could be removed by soaking the MOF in MeOH over a period of 24 h to generate 1-CoCl3(MeOH) (Figure S16). This washing procedure does not affect the bulk crystallinity of the MOF but does exacerbate decomposition of the pincer complex as observed from the solid-state 31P NMR spectrum (). Moreover, the two distinct 31P NMR resonances that were present in the solid-state spectrum of 1-CoCl3  merge into a broad signal centered at 65 ppm in 1-CoCl3(MeOH). Efforts to remove the impurities with other solvents such as acetone, DMF, or THF were unsuccessful.

elements.content: TGA analysis of 1-CoCl3 shows a ∼53% mass loss up to 200 °C, consistent with the loss of guest solvent molecules from the porous framework (Figure S18). However, N2 adsorption isotherms (77 K) measured for a sample of 1-CoCl3(MeOH) desolvated by heating under reduced pressure (10–4 Torr, 100 °C) showed low N2 uptake and gave a calculated Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area of 366 m2 g–1 (Figure S19). X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) analysis of the desolvated samples revealed nearly complete loss of crystallinity, and attempts to activate 1-CoCl3 prior to solvent exchange or employ milder activation conditions to 1-CoCl3(MeOH) gave similar results. Despite its apparent structural collapse upon desolvation, 1-CoCl3(MeOH) retains guest accessible porosity when suspended in organic solvents as evidenced by its amenability to PSME (vide infra).

X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) analysis of the desolvated samples revealed nearly complete loss of crystallinity, and attempts to activate 1-CoCl3  prior to solvent exchange or employ milder activation conditions to 1-CoCl3(MeOH) gave similar results. Despite its apparent structural collapse upon desolvation, 1-CoCl3(MeOH) retains guest accessible porosity when suspended in organic solvents as evidenced by its amenability to PSME (vide infra).

elements.content: ICP-OES analysis of 1-CoCl3(MeOH) provided a Zr/Co ratio of 6:1.66, which is larger than that expected for a defect-free structure (Zr/Co = 6:2), but is in line with the presence of decomposed linker species observed in the solid-state 31P NMR spectra. The Co deficiency is also consistent with the low occupancy of the [L-CoCl3]4– linkers determined from the Rietveld refinement. The 31P NMR spectrum of an acid-digested sample of activated 1-CoCl3(MeOH) exhibits a minor signal at 33.5 ppm, implicating the phosphinic acid species (Ar2PO2H, Ar = p-C6H4CO2 –) as the linker decomposition product (Figure S17). Integration of the spectrum shows that Ar2PO2H is present in a ∼0.2:1 ratio with respect to H4(L-CoCl3). The corresponding 1H NMR spectrum again shows the presence of CH3CO2H as well as ∼1.3 equiv of MeOH per linker (Figure S16). On the basis of the spectroscopic and analytical data, the empirical formula of desolvated 1-CoCl3(MeOH) is best provided as [Zr6O4(OH)4]­(OH)2.2(MeOH)2.2(OAc)2.5(L-CoCl3)1.66(Ar2PO2H)0.33.

elements.content: In the course of our investigations, we observed that heating a suspension of 1-CoCl3(MeOH) in DMF at 85 °C resulted in the formation of a green supernatant solution. Monitoring the thermolysis via X-ray fluorescence (XRF) spectroscopy revealed a substantial loss of Co from the framework while XRPD analysis showed a decline in sample crystallinity (Figures S20 and S21). A similar experiment carried out with the homogeneous pincer complex tBu4(L-CoCl3) also resulted in formation of a green solution and disappearance of the corresponding 31P NMR signal at 67.2 ppm. Together these results pointed to surprisingly facile demetalation of the [L-CoCl3]4– linkers, and we sought to leverage this behavior to access pincer MOFs that have proven difficult or impossible to assemble under direct solvothermal conditions. For example, the RhI pincer complex tBu4(L-RhCl) is highly susceptible to oxidation and has so far been incompatible with the deprotection conditions necessary for direct synthesis of a Zr MOF. In addition, linkers based on PdII and PtII diphosphine pincer complexes have been observed to form Zr MOFs with a ftw topology, but polymorphs with the csq topology have not been accessible by direct solvothermal synthesis. Consequently, we set out to elucidate the mechanism of demetalation of the CoIII-PNNNP pincer complexes and investigate Rh/Co and Pt/Co postsynthetic metal exchange in 1-CoCl3(MeOH).
elements.clean_text:
Postsynthetic Metal Exchange

In the course of our investigations, we observed that heating a suspension of 1-CoCl3(MeOH) in DMF at 85 °C resulted in the formation of a green supernatant solution. Monitoring the thermolysis via X-ray fluorescence (XRF) spectroscopy revealed a substantial loss of Co from the framework while XRPD analysis showed a decline in sample crystallinity (Figures S20 and S21). A similar experiment carried out with the homogeneous pincer complex tBu4(L-CoCl3) also resulted in formation of a green solution and disappearance of the corresponding 31P NMR signal at 67.2 ppm. Together these results pointed to surprisingly facile demetalation of the [L-CoCl3]4- linkers, and we sought to leverage this behavior to access pincer MOFs that have proven difficult or impossible to assemble under direct solvothermal conditions. For example, the RhI pincer complex tBu4(L-RhCl) is highly susceptible to oxidation and has so far been incompatible with the deprotection conditions necessary for direct synthesis of a Zr MOF. In addition, linkers based on PdII and PtII diphosphine pincer complexes have been observed to form Zr MOFs with a ftw topology, but polymorphs with the csq topology have not been accessible by direct solvothermal synthesis. Consequently, we set out to elucidate the mechanism of demetalation of the CoIII-PNNNP pincer complexes and investigate Rh/Co and Pt/Co postsynthetic metal exchange in 1-CoCl3(MeOH).

elements.content: In order to establish the ability of the CoIII-PNNNP pincer species to undergo metal exchange, preliminary reactions were carried out with the homogeneous complex tBu4(L-CoCl3) (a). A solution of tBu4(L-CoCl3) and [Rh­(nbd)­Cl]2 (0.5 equiv, nbd = 2,5-norbornadiene) in DMSO-d 6 was monitored by 31P NMR spectroscopy at room temperature. Within 4 h, the spectrum showed complete disappearance of the signal corresponding to tBu4(L-CoCl3) concomitant with the appearance of two new doublet resonances centered at 80 ppm (1 J Rh–P = 154.7 Hz) and 65 ppm (1 J Rh–P = 93.7 Hz) in a 2:1 ratio, respectively (Figure S23). The doublet at 80 ppm matches that observed for a sample of tBu4(L-RhCl) synthesized by direct reaction of tBu4(L) with [Rh­(nbd)­Cl]2, while the upfield shift and smaller 1 J Rh–P coupling for the signal at 65 ppm prompts its assignment as the RhIII pincer complex tBu4(L-RhCl3). The presence of the RhIII pincer complex reveals that a redox reaction occurs between RhI and CoIII during the metal exchange process and reduction of CoIII to a more labile CoII species is likely a key factor in demetalation of the PNNNP pincer complexes. In support of this notion, tBu4(L-CoCl3) showed no signs of demetalation upon heating at 85 °C in DMSO solution (Figure S24). However, the corresponding 31P NMR signal quickly disappeared upon addition of a stoichiometric amount of NEt3 at room temperature, indicating that NEt3 causes reduction to a paramagnetic CoII-PNNNP species (Figure S25). Moreover, when a THF suspension of 1-CoCl3(MeOH) was heated at 60 °C in the presence of NEt3 (∼2 equiv per Co), the solid underwent a color change from orange to light pink. XRPD analysis showed that the MOF retains crystallinity, and a large increase in the EPR signal compared to the spectrum measured for 1-CoCl3(MeOH) confirms the formation of paramagnetic CoII species (Figures S26 and S27). Thus it appears that the demetalation of the CoIII-PNNNP pincer complexes observed in DMF solution is facilitated by the ability of the solvent to reduce CoIII to CoII and stabilize the expelled metal ion. When the metal exchange reaction between tBu4(L-CoCl3) and [Rh­(nbd)­Cl]2 was carried out in DMSO solution containing NEt3 as a sacrificial reductant, tBu4(L-RhCl) was observed as the sole product (Figure S28). Altogether these results support an exchange mechanism that involves initial reduction of CoIII to CoII (b).

elements.content: Guided by the mechanistic information obtained from the homogeneous complex, Rh/Co PSME was investigated for 1-CoCl3(MeOH). No metal exchange was observed when a sample of 1-CoCl3(MeOH) was treated with a solution of [Rh­(nbd)­Cl]2 in DMSO at room temperature for 12 h. However, heating the suspension at 85 °C resulted in the formation of 1-RhCl as a bright yellow solid (). The progress of Rh/Co metal exchange was monitored by XRF (a), and within 6 h, the Co-based emission signal had nearly disappeared, concomitant with the appearance of a new Rh signal. Similar results were obtained when the PSME reaction was carried out in the presence of a stoichiometric amount of NEt3 to generate 1-RhCl­(NEt3). ICP-OES analysis of 1-RhCl and 1-RhCl­(NEt3) provided Zr/Rh/Co ratios of 6:1.64:0.03 and 6:1.33:0.15, respectively, confirming nearly complete Rh/Co exchange based on the empirical formula previously derived for 1-CoCl3(MeOH). The solid-state 31P NMR spectra of 1-RhCl and 1-RhCl­(NEt3) both display two major resonances centered at 79 and 65 ppm that can be assigned as RhI and RhIII pincer species, respectively (b). Similar to the spectra measured for 1-CoCl3(MeOH), minor signals (∼23%) attributed to decomposed linker species are observed in the 15–30 ppm region. Integration of the spectrum of 1-RhCl shows a ∼1:1 ratio of RhI/RhIII pincer species, while the addition of NEt3 resulted in an increase to a ∼2:1 RhI/RhIII ratio for 1-RhCl­(NEt3). Thus, while NEt3 appears to maintain its role as a sacrificial reductant, it is less effective in the MOF than for the homogeneous complex. Attempts to prevent the oxidation of RhI by performing the exchange reaction in the presence of increased amounts of NEt3 resulted in little change in the RhI/RhIII ratio observed by solid-state 31P NMR (Figure S32). Moreover, the use of DMF in place of DMSO resulted in Rh/Co metal exchange, but was accompanied by the formation of Rh nanoparticles (Figure S33).

elements.content: The XRPD pattern of 1-RhCl confirmed that the framework structure is retained after the PSME reaction (a). Indexing and Pawley fitting of SXPD data shows a slight increase in the unit cell parameters (a = 32.9152(9) Å, c = 15.5342(5) Å) compared to 1-CoCl3 (Table S1). These changes are consistent with chelation of the larger Rh species by the PNNNP pincer ligands but also could be influenced by differences in the identity of guest solvent molecules that occupy the framework channels: DMF for 1-CoCl3 and DMSO for 1-RhCl. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of 1-CoCl3(MeOH) and 1-RhCl show similar morphologies with small particles in the range of 100–300 nm (Figures S34 and S35). In addition, elemental mapping using energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) indicates a uniform distribution of Zr and Rh across the sample of 1-RhCl (Figure S35). Similar to 1-CoCl3 , a desolvated sample of 1-RhCl showed only modest N2 uptake at 77 K, providing a calculated BET surface area of 316 m2 g–1 (Figure S37). However, the CO adsorption isotherm (303 K) reveals a steep chemisorption step with an uptake of 0.35 mmol g–1 at 0.1 bar (b). The CO was not readily desorbed upon evacuation of the sample or heating under vacuum (10–4 Torr, 373 K). The CO uptake by 1-RhCl is significantly larger than that observed for 1-CoCl3 and corresponds to chemisorption at ∼62% of the Rh sites in the MOF, which is consistent with fraction of RhI sites determined by 31P NMR. The ATR-IR spectrum of 1-RhCl after the CO sorption experiment shows a strong CO stretch at 2013 cm–1, in line with the formation of RhCl­(CO)-PNNNP species (Figure S38). Furthermore, the solid-state 31P NMR spectrum after CO sorption shows that the signal corresponding to the RhI pincer metallolinkers shifts slightly downfield to 86 ppm, while that assigned to the RhIII pincer species at ∼65 ppm is not affected (Figure S39).

elements.content: Next, we sought to investigate the generation of 1-PtCl via Pt/Co exchange. A suspension of 1-CoCl3(MeOH) in a DMSO solution containing PtCl2(SMe2)2 and NEt3 was heated at 85 °C, resulting in the formation of 1-PtCl as an off-white microcrystalline powder (). XRF analysis indicated nearly quantitative Pt/Co exchange after 24 h (a), while XRPD confirmed that the framework retains crystallinity (a). Indexing and Pawley fitting of the SXPD data provided unit cell parameters (a = 33.0244(6) Å, c = 15.3783(4) Å) similar to those of 1-RhCl (Table S1). Monitoring of the reaction by XRF showed that the Pt/Co exchange approaches completion after ∼12 h and is slower than the Rh/Co PSME reaction (Figures S41 and S42). No metal exchange was observed in the absence of NEt3, which is consistent with the higher oxidation potential of PtII compared to RhI and the inability of the former to reduce the CoIII-PNNNP complex. ICP-OES analysis provided a Zr/Pt/Co ratio of 6:1.96:0.05, indicating that the MOF contains slightly more Pt than expected based on the analyses of 1-CoCl3 and 1-RhCl. XRPD patterns of 1-PtCl showed no indication of the presence of Pt nanoparticles, suggesting that despite extensive washing, a small amount of homogeneous Pt species likely remain trapped in the framework. The solid-state 31P NMR spectrum of 1-PtCl (b) shows a broad resonance centered at 62.5 ppm that is consistent with the signal observed for the homogeneous complex [tBu4(L-PtCl)]­Cl­(62.6 ppm, 1 J 195Pt–31P = 2812 Hz) and the solid-state NMR data previously reported for 2-PtX. In addition, the solution-state 31P NMR spectrum of an acid-digested sample of 1-PtCl shows a single resonance at 63.2 ppm with characteristic 195Pt–31P coupling (Figure S43).

elements.content: Lastly, we sought to take advantage of the slow Pt/Co exchange to generate a mixed-metal MOF containing both Pt and Rh pincer complexes. A suspension of 1-CoCl3(MeOH) in DMSO was treated with PtCl2(SMe2)2 and NEt3 at 85 °C for 10 h. After decanting the reaction supernatant, the solid was treated with a solution of [Rh­(nbd)­Cl]2 in DMSO for an additional 12 h to generate 1-PtRh (). XRF analysis confirmed the presence of both Pt and Rh in the solid product with nearly complete exchange of Co (c). This is further supported by ICP-OES analysis which provided a Zr/Pt/Rh/Co ratio of 6:1.38:0.5:0.05. 31P NMR analysis of an acid-digested sample of 1-PtRh showed a signal at 63 ppm that is consistent with the presence of [L-PtCl]4– linkers (Figure S44). Several resonances with characteristic 103Rh–31P coupling are also observed in the 64–70 ppm region. The observation of multiple different RhIII-PNNNP species is the result of oxidation induced by the acid digestion procedure, but nonetheless confirms Rh/Co exchange at the pincer sites.

XRF analysis confirmed the presence of both Pt and Rh in the solid product with nearly complete exchange of Co (c). This is further supported by ICP-OES analysis which provided a Zr/Pt/Rh/Co ratio of 6:1.38:0.5:0.05. 31P NMR analysis of an acid-digested sample of 1-PtRh showed a signal at 63 ppm that is consistent with the presence of [L-PtCl]4- linkers (Figure S44). elements.content: In summary, we report the synthesis and structure of 1-CoCl3 , which contains linkers based on CoIII-PNNNP pincer complexes. 1-CoCl3 adopts a structure with csq topology while previously reported Zr MOFs containing Pd- and Pt-PNNNP pincer complexes form structures with ftw topology. The different structures indicate that the coordination geometry of the pincer-ligated metal fragment (i.e., pseudo-octahedral versus square planar) strongly influences MOF assembly. On the basis of trends observed for Zr MOFs containing other tetratopic linkers, we surmise that the axial Cl– ligands in H4(L-CoCl3) inhibit rotation of the benzoate arms, enforcing a conformation that favors formation of the csq topology MOF. The CoIII-PNNNP pincer complex is sufficiently inert to allow for MOF assembly upon heating in a DMF/HOAc/HCl solvent mixture. However, heating a suspension of 1-CoCl3 in DMF results in rapid demetalation of the PNNNP ligands. The presence of mild reducing agents such as amines has been shown to result in reduction to a labile CoII species that is responsible for the observed demetalation. This process has been exploited to carry out Rh/Co and Pt/Co PSME with 1-CoCl3 . These facile metal substitutions provide access to 1-RhCl and 1-PtCl, which have not yet been obtained by direct solvothermal synthesis. Moreover, the PSME reactions occur on time scales that allow for sequential metal exchange, as demonstrated by generation of the mixed metal pincer MOF 1-PtRh. Linker-based metal exchange reactions have been relatively rare in MOFs and demetalation or metal exchange reactions with diphosphine pincer ligands are largely unprecedented. Consequently, the findings described herein offer a new pathway for the introduction of metal-based functionalities that are difficult to access by direct synthesis and may have ramifications in both homogeneous and heterogeneous systems. We anticipate that the PSME reactions will be advantageous for the design of new MOF-based catalysts and our continuing investigations are focused on exploring the reactivity and catalytic activity of 1-RhCl, 1-PtCl, and other pincer MOFs derived from PSME.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, we report the synthesis and structure of 1-CoCl3 , which contains linkers based on CoIII-PNNNP pincer complexes. 1-CoCl3  adopts a structure with csq topology while previously reported Zr MOFs containing Pd- and Pt-PNNNP pincer complexes form structures with ftw topology. The different structures indicate that the coordination geometry of the pincer-ligated metal fragment (i.e., pseudo-octahedral versus square planar) strongly influences MOF assembly. On the basis of trends observed for Zr MOFs containing other tetratopic linkers, we surmise that the axial Cl- ligands in H4(L-CoCl3) inhibit rotation of the benzoate arms, enforcing a conformation that favors formation of the csq topology MOF. The CoIII-PNNNP pincer complex is sufficiently inert to allow for MOF assembly upon heating in a DMF/HOAc/HCl solvent mixture. However, heating a suspension of 1-CoCl3  in DMF results in rapid demetalation of the PNNNP ligands. The presence of mild reducing agents such as amines has been shown to result in reduction to a labile CoII species that is responsible for the observed demetalation. This process has been exploited to carry out Rh/Co and Pt/Co PSME with 1-CoCl3 . These facile metal substitutions provide access to 1-RhCl and 1-PtCl, which have not yet been obtained by direct solvothermal synthesis. Moreover, the PSME reactions occur on time scales that allow for sequential metal exchange, as demonstrated by generation of the mixed metal pincer MOF 1-PtRh. Linker-based metal exchange reactions have been relatively rare in MOFs and demetalation or metal exchange reactions with diphosphine pincer ligands are largely unprecedented. Consequently, the findings described herein offer a new pathway for the introduction of metal-based functionalities that are difficult to access by direct synthesis and may have ramifications in both homogeneous and heterogeneous systems. We anticipate that the PSME reactions will be advantageous for the design of new MOF-based catalysts and our continuing investigations are focused on exploring the reactivity and catalytic activity of 1-RhCl, 1-PtCl, and other pincer MOFs derived from PSME.

elements.content: tBu4(L), [CoCl2(C5H5N)4]­Cl, [Rh­(CO)2Cl]2, PtCl2(SMe2)2, and [Rh­(nbd)­Cl]2 were prepared following literature procedures. All metal exchange reactions were carried out in a nitrogen-filled glovebox using solvents that were dried over CaH2 and distilled or dried via passage through columns of drying agents using a solvent purification system from Pure Process Technologies. Other solvents and reagents were purchased from commercial suppliers and used as received. Routine XRPD patterns for phase identification were collected using a Rigaku Miniflex 600 diffractometer with Nickel-filtered Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). High-resolution synchrotron X-ray powder diffraction (SXPD) data were collected at 295 K using beamline 11-BM at the Advanced Photon Source (APS, Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, IL) with an average wavelength of 0.412697 Å. Initial structural models for 1-CoCl3 were constructed from the positions of the heavy atoms located using a charge flipping method within the PDXL2 Structure Analysis Package (Rigaku Corporation). Rietveld refinement was carried out with TOPAS-Academic. A Bruker Tracer III-SD Hand-held XRF Analyzer with a rhodium target and silicon drift detector at 40 keV voltage and 10 μA current was used to monitor metal exchange reactions. ATR-IR spectra were measured using a Nicolet IR 200 with a diamond ATR accessory. N2 (77 K, liquid nitrogen bath) and CO (303 K) adsorption isotherms were measured using a Micromeritics 3Flex Surface Characterization Analyzer. Prior to analysis, samples (100–200 mg) were heated under reduced pressure until the outgas rate was less than 2 mTorr/min. Inductively coupled plasma–optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) measurements were performed by Robertson Microlit Laboratories (Ledgewood, NJ) or the Trace Element Research Laboratory at the Ohio State University. Other elemental analyses (C, H, N, Cl) were performed by Robertson Microlit Laboratories (Ledgewood, NJ) or Atlantic Microlab (Norcross, GA). SEM and elemental mapping of metals using EDX were performed at the Center for Electron Microscopy and Analysis (CEMAS) at The Ohio State University using a Thermo Scientic Apreo LoVac Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscope. The samples were prepared by dispersing MOF powders onto double-sided, conductive carbon tape that was attached to an aluminum sample holder. Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra were collected at 10 K using a Bruker EMXPlus Electron Paramagnetic Resonance Spectrometer. Samples were prepared by suspending the MOFs in THF solvent in 4 mm quartz EPR tubes. Solution-state NMR spectra were measured using either a Varian Inova or Bruker 400 MHz spectrometer (162 MHz operating frequency for 31P). For 1H and 13C­{1H} NMR spectra, the solvent resonance was referenced as an internal standard. For 31P NMR spectra, 85% H3PO4 was used as an external standard (0 ppm). Solid-state NMR experiments were performed using a Bruker DSX-400 spectrometer at a resonance frequency of 162 MHz for 31P with a magic-angle spinning (MAS) probe in double-resonance mode. Samples were packed into 4 mm rotors with Kel-F 22 μL inserts. Experiments were carried out at spinning frequencies of 10–13.5 kHz. Typical 31P and 1H 90° pulse-lengths were 4 and 6 μs, respectively. 31P NMR spectra were obtained after composite-pulse multiple cross-polarization from 1H, with a recycle delay of 1 s and 10 blocks of 1.1 ms 90–100% ramp cross-polarization separated by 0.5 s 1H repolarization periods. Four-pulse total suppression of sidebands (TOSS) was used to obtain spectra without spinning sidebands. Two-pulse phase modulation 1H decoupling was applied during detection. 31P spectra were externally referenced to the upfield resonance of calcium hydroxyapatite (National Institute of Standards and Technology) at 2.73 ppm; this corresponds to the 85% H3PO4 scale.

Experimental Section

General Considerations

 tBu4(L), [CoCl2(C5H5N)4]Cl, [Rh(CO)2Cl]2, PtCl2(SMe2)2, and [Rh(nbd)Cl]2  were prepared following literature procedures. All metal exchange reactions were carried out in a nitrogen-filled glovebox using solvents that were dried over CaH2 and distilled or dried via passage through columns of drying agents using a solvent purification system from Pure Process Technologies. Other solvents and reagents were purchased from commercial suppliers and used as received. Routine XRPD patterns for phase identification were collected using a Rigaku Miniflex 600 diffractometer with Nickel-filtered Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). High-resolution synchrotron X-ray powder diffraction (SXPD) data were collected at 295 K using beamline 11-BM at the Advanced Photon Source (APS, Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, IL) with an average wavelength of 0.412697 Å. Initial structural models for 1-CoCl3  were constructed from the positions of the heavy atoms located using a charge flipping method within the PDXL2 Structure Analysis Package (Rigaku Corporation). Rietveld refinement was carried out with TOPAS-Academic. A Bruker Tracer III-SD Hand-held XRF Analyzer with a rhodium target and silicon drift detector at 40 keV voltage and 10 μA current was used to monitor metal exchange reactions. ATR-IR spectra were measured using a Nicolet IR 200 with a diamond ATR accessory. N2 (77 K, liquid nitrogen bath) and CO (303 K) adsorption isotherms were measured using a Micromeritics 3Flex Surface Characterization Analyzer. Prior to analysis, samples (100-200 mg) were heated under reduced pressure until the outgas rate was less than 2 mTorr/min. Inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) measurements were performed by Robertson Microlit Laboratories (Ledgewood, NJ) or the Trace Element Research Laboratory at the Ohio State University. Other elemental analyses (C, H, N, Cl) were performed by Robertson Microlit Laboratories (Ledgewood, NJ) or Atlantic Microlab (Norcross, GA). SEM and elemental mapping of metals using EDX were performed at the Center for Electron Microscopy and Analysis (CEMAS) at The Ohio State University using a Thermo Scientic Apreo LoVac Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscope. The samples were prepared by dispersing MOF powders onto double-sided, conductive carbon tape that was attached to an aluminum sample holder. Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra were collected at 10 K using a Bruker EMXPlus Electron Paramagnetic Resonance Spectrometer. Samples were prepared by suspending the MOFs in THF solvent in 4 mm quartz EPR tubes. Solution-state NMR spectra were measured using either a Varian Inova or Bruker 400 MHz spectrometer (162 MHz operating frequency for 31P). For 1H and 13C{1H} NMR spectra, the solvent resonance was referenced as an internal standard. For 31P NMR spectra, 85% H3PO4 was used as an external standard (0 ppm). Solid-state NMR experiments were performed using a Bruker DSX-400 spectrometer at a resonance frequency of 162 MHz for 31P with a magic-angle spinning (MAS) probe in double-resonance mode. Samples were packed into 4 mm rotors with Kel-F 22 μL inserts. Experiments were carried out at spinning frequencies of 10-13.5 kHz. Typical 31P and 1H 90° pulse-lengths were 4 and 6 μs, respectively. 31P NMR spectra were obtained after composite-pulse multiple cross-polarization from 1H, with a recycle delay of 1 s and 10 blocks of 1.1 ms 90-100% ramp cross-polarization separated by 0.5 s 1H repolarization periods. Four-pulse total suppression of sidebands (TOSS) was used to obtain spectra without spinning sidebands. Two-pulse phase modulation 1H decoupling was applied during detection. 31P spectra were externally referenced to the upfield resonance of calcium hydroxyapatite (National Institute of Standards and Technology) at 2.73 ppm; this corresponds to the 85% H3PO4 scale.

elements.content: A 20 mL scintillation vial was charged with ZrCl4 (0.05 g, 0.21 mmol), DMF (12 mL), and glacial acetic acid (3 mL) and sonicated for 20 min. Concentrated HCl (3 mL) followed by H4(L-CoCl3) (0.06 g, 0.07 mmol) were added to the vial, and the resulting orange solution was sonicated for 2 min to ensure complete dissolution. The reaction vial was sealed with a Teflon-lined screw-top cap (Qorpak CAP-00554), placed in a room temperature oven, and heated to 80 °C for 16 h. After cooling to room temperature, the resulting solid was collected by centrifugation and washed with DMF (3 × 12 mL) to afford 1-CoCl3 . The product was soaked in methanol (4 × 10 mL) over the course of 24 h to afford 1-CoCl3(MeOH) (0.07 g). Acid-digested 31P­{1H} NMR (162 MHz, CF3CO2H/C6D6): δ 67.6 (H4L-CoCl3), 67.2 (H4L-CoCl2(OH)), 33.5 (Ar2PO2H). Anal. Calcd for 1-CoCl3(MeOH); [Zr6O4OH4]­(OH)2.2(MeOH)2.2(C33H21N3O8P2 CoCl3)1.66(CH3CO2)2.5(C14H9O6P)0.33: C, 33.50; H, 2.55; N; 2.92; Cl, 7.39. Found: C, 31.64; H, 2.96; N, 2.62; Cl, 7.04. ICP-OES: Zr, 23; Co, 3.35. Diaryl phosphinic acid linker fragments [(p-C6H4–CO2)2PO2H] resulting from linker decomposition have been included in the empirical formula based on the minor resonances observed in the solid state and acid-digested 31P NMR spectra.

elements.content: A solution of [Rh­(nbd)­Cl]2 (0.06 g, 0.14 mmol) in DMSO (3 mL) was added to a suspension 1-CoCl3(MeOH) (0.18 g, 0.07 mmol) in DMSO (12 mL) in a 20 mL scintillation vial. The reaction vial was sealed with a Teflon-lined screw-top cap (Qorpak CAP-00554) and heated at 85 °C for 12 h. The reaction supernatant became dark green, while the solid turned bright yellow within 2 h. After cooling, the solid was collected by centrifugation, and washed with DMSO (∼5 × 10 mL) and methanol (3 × 10 mL over the course of 24 h). The solid was briefly dried in vacuo to give 1-RhCl (0.32 g) as a yellow microcrystalline powder. TGA analysis of the sample showed a 38 wt % mass loss up to 200 °C, attributable to volatilization of DMSO solvent from the framework. Attempts to digest samples of 1-RhCl with CF3CO2H and organic solvents resulted in oxidation of the Rh-PNNNP linkers to a mixture of RhIII species. For kinetic analyses of the reaction, the progress of metal exchange was monitored by XRF every 2 h for a period of 12 h. Solid samples were obtained by removing aliquots of the reaction mixture, collecting the solid by centrifugation, and washing with DMSO until the color disappeared from the supernatant (∼5 × 10 mL). ICP-OES: Zr, 21.79; Rh, 5.86; Co, 0.06.

cln_elements.content:
A solution of [CoCl2(C5H5N)4]Cl (0.22 g, 0.44 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (5 mL) was added to a solution of tBu4(L) (0.40 g, 0.44 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (5 mL) under a N2 atmosphere. An immediate color change to deep red was observed, and a solution of [(n-Bu)4N]Cl (0.08 g, 0.22 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (3 mL) was added. The reaction was heated at 35 °C with vigorous stirring for 16 h before removing the volatiles under reduced pressure to afford a red solid. Residual pyridine was removed by dissolving the solid in toluene (10 mL) and evaporating to dryness using a rotatory evaporator at least three times. The crude material was then dissolved in minimal amount of CH2Cl2 and filtered through a plug of silica using ethyl acetate as eluent. Volatiles were removed under vacuum, and the product was obtained as a red powder (0.40 g, 84%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, (CD3)2CO): δ 1.58 (s, 36H, tBu), 6.60 (d, 2H, 3 J H–H = 8.78 Hz, pyridine Ar–H), 7.52 (t, 1H, 3 J H–H = 7.98 Hz, pyridine Ar–H), 7.99 (d, 8H, 3 J H–H = 7.42 Hz, benzoate Ar–H), 8.36 (dt, 8H, 3 J P–H = 13.09 Hz, 3 J H–H = 7.67 Hz, benzoate Ar–H), 9.40 (br, 2H, N–H). 13C­{1H} NMR (101 MHz, (CD3)2CO): δ 27.3 (s, 12C, C­(CH3)3), 80.9 (s, 4C, C­(CH3)3), 101.5 (br, 2C, Ar), 128.4 (t, J = 5.54 Hz, 8C, Ar), 132.5 (t, J = 5.71 Hz, 8C, Ar), 133.8 (s, 4C), 137.7 (t, J = 27.20 Hz, 4C, Ar), 141.1 (s, C, Ar), 160.9 (t, J = 9.64 Hz, 2C, Ar), 164.6 (s, 4C, CO2). 31P­{1H} NMR (162 MHz, (CD3)2CO): δ 67.47 (s, 2P). Anal. Calcd for tBu4L-CoCl3; C49H57Cl3CoN3O8P2: C, 56.41; H, 5.51; N, 4.03. Found: C, 55.23; H, 5.42; N, 4.05.

Synthesis of H<sub>4</sub>(L-CoCl<sub>3</sub>)

A 20 mL scintillation vial was charged with tBu4(L-CoCl3) (0.40 g, 0.38 mmol), CH2Cl2 (3 mL), CF3CO2H (1 mL), and concentrated HCl (0.1 mL). The resulting solution was stirred at room temperature for 16 h. Deionized water (10 mL) was added to the reaction, resulting in formation of an orange precipitate. The mixture was sonicated briefly and stirred for 15 min. The solid was then collected by filtration, washed with deionized water (2 × 10 mL) and CHCl3 (3 × 10 mL), and dried under reduced pressure to yield H4(L-CoCl3) as an orange powder (0.30 g, 88%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, (CD3)2CO) δ 6.68 (d, 2H, 3 J H–H = 8.24 Hz, pyridine Ar–H), 7.55 (t, 1H, 3 J H–H = 8.37 Hz, pyridine Ar–H), 8.11 (d, 8H, 3 J H–H = 8.59 Hz, benzoate Ar–H), 8.42 (m, 8H, benzoate Ar–H), 9.49 (br, 2H, NH). 13C­{1H} NMR (101 MHz, (CD3)2CO) δ 101.3 (br, 2C, Ar), 128.7 (t, J = 5.47 Hz, 8C, Ar), 132.5 (t, J = 5.71 Hz, 8C, Ar), 138.0 (t, J = 27.8 Hz, 4C Ar), 141.1 (s, C), 160.9 (t, J = 9.40 Hz, 2C,Ar), 166.3 (s, 4C, CO2). 31P­{1H} NMR (162 MHz, (CD3)2CO): δ 67.30 (s, 2P). Anal. Calcd for H4L-CoCl3.(2H2O); C33H29Cl3CoN3O10P2: C, 46.37; H, 3.42; N, 4.92. Found: C, 45.73; H, 3.84; N, 4.82.

Synthesis of <bold>1-CoCl<sub>3</sub> </bold> and <bold>1-CoCl<sub>3</sub>(MeOH)</bold>

A 20 mL scintillation vial was charged with ZrCl4 (0.05 g, 0.21 mmol), DMF (12 mL), and glacial acetic acid (3 mL) and sonicated for 20 min. Concentrated HCl (3 mL) followed by H4(L-CoCl3) (0.06 g, 0.07 mmol) were added to the vial, and the resulting orange solution was sonicated for 2 min to ensure complete dissolution. The reaction vial was sealed with a Teflon-lined screw-top cap (Qorpak CAP-00554), placed in a room temperature oven, and heated to 80 °C for 16 h. After cooling to room temperature, the resulting solid was collected by centrifugation and washed with DMF (3 × 12 mL) to afford 1-CoCl3 . The product was soaked in methanol (4 × 10 mL) over the course of 24 h to afford 1-CoCl3(MeOH) (0.07 g). Acid-digested 31P­{1H} NMR (162 MHz, CF3CO2H/C6D6): δ 67.6 (H4L-CoCl3), 67.2 (H4L-CoCl2(OH)), 33.5 (Ar2PO2H). Anal. Calcd for 1-CoCl3(MeOH); [Zr6O4OH4]­(OH)2.2(MeOH)2.2(C33H21N3O8P2 CoCl3)1.66(CH3CO2)2.5(C14H9O6P)0.33: C, 33.50; H, 2.55; N; 2.92; Cl, 7.39. Found: C, 31.64; H, 2.96; N, 2.62; Cl, 7.04. ICP-OES: Zr, 23; Co, 3.35. Diaryl phosphinic acid linker fragments [(p-C6H4–CO2)2PO2H] resulting from linker decomposition have been included in the empirical formula based on the minor resonances observed in the solid state and acid-digested 31P NMR spectra.

Preparation of <bold>1-RhCl</bold>

A solution of [Rh­(nbd)­Cl]2 (0.06 g, 0.14 mmol) in DMSO (3 mL) was added to a suspension 1-CoCl3(MeOH) (0.18 g, 0.07 mmol) in DMSO (12 mL) in a 20 mL scintillation vial. The reaction vial was sealed with a Teflon-lined screw-top cap (Qorpak CAP-00554) and heated at 85 °C for 12 h. The reaction supernatant became dark green, while the solid turned bright yellow within 2 h. After cooling, the solid was collected by centrifugation, and washed with DMSO (∼5 × 10 mL) and methanol (3 × 10 mL over the course of 24 h). The solid was briefly dried in vacuo to give 1-RhCl (0.32 g) as a yellow microcrystalline powder. TGA analysis of the sample showed a 38 wt % mass loss up to 200 °C, attributable to volatilization of DMSO solvent from the framework. Attempts to digest samples of 1-RhCl with CF3CO2H and organic solvents resulted in oxidation of the Rh-PNNNP linkers to a mixture of RhIII species. For kinetic analyses of the reaction, the progress of metal exchange was monitored by XRF every 2 h for a period of 12 h. Solid samples were obtained by removing aliquots of the reaction mixture, collecting the solid by centrifugation, and washing with DMSO until the color disappeared from the supernatant (∼5 × 10 mL). ICP-OES: Zr, 21.79; Rh, 5.86; Co, 0.06.

Preparation of <bold>1-RhCl­(NEt<sub>3</sub>)</bold>

A solution of [Rh­(nbd)­Cl]2 (0.060 g, 0.14 mmol) in DMSO (3 mL) and NEt3(0.1 M in DMSO, 0.04 mmol) was added to a suspension of 1-CoCl3(MeOH) (0.18 g, 0.07 mmol) in DMSO (12 mL) in a 20 mL scintillation vial. The reaction mixture was heated at 85 °C for 12 h. The reaction supernatant became dark green, while the solid turned bright yellow within 2 h. After allowing the reaction to cool to room temperature, the solid was collected by centrifugation, washed with DMSO (5 × 10 mL) and soaked in methanol for 24 h (3 × 10 mL). ICP-OES: Zr, 20.16; Rh, 5.04; Co, 0.32.

Preparation of <bold>1-PtCl</bold>

A solution of PtCl2(SMe2)2 (0.11 g, 0.28 mmol) in DMSO (3 mL) and NEt3 (0.1 M in DMSO, 0.04 mmol) was added to a suspension of 1-CoCl3(MeOH) (0.18 g, 0.07 mmol) in DMSO (12 mL) in a 20 mL scintillation vial. The reaction vial was sealed with a Teflon-lined screw-top cap (Qorpak CAP-00554) and heated at 85 °C for 24 h. After allowing the reaction to cool to room temperature, the solid was collected by centrifugation and washed with DMSO (5 × 10 mL) or until the supernatant of the reaction became colorless. The solid was briefly dried in vacuo to give 1-PtCl (0.30 g) as a yellow microcrystalline powder. TGA analysis of the sample showed a 34 wt % mass loss up to 200 °C, attributable to volatilization of DMSO solvent from the framework. Acid-digested 31P­{1H} NMR (162 MHz, CF3CO2H/C6D6): δ 63.20 (J 195Pt–31P = 2814 Hz). ICP-OES: Zr, 19.0; Pt, 13.3; Co, 0.07.

Preparation of <bold>1-RhPt</bold>

PtCl2(SMe2)2 (0.11 g, 0.28 mmol) in DMSO (3 mL) and NEt3 (0.1 M in DMSO, 0.04 mmol) was added to a suspension of 1-CoCl3(MeOH) (0.18 g, 0.07 mmol) in DMSO (12 mL). The reaction vial was sealed with Teflon-lined screw-top cap (Qorpak CAP-00554) and heated at 85 °C for 10 h. After allowing the reaction to cool to room temperature, the supernatant was removed via centrifugation. The solid was resuspended in fresh DMSO (12 mL), a solution of [RhCl­(nbd)]2 (0.03 g, 0.07 mmol) in DMSO (3 mL) added, and the mixture was heated at 85 °C for 12 h. After cooling the reaction to room temperature, the supernatant was decanted, and the solid was washed with DMSO (5 × 10 mL). 31P­{1H} NMR (162 MHz, CF3CO2H/C6D6): δ 68.3 (d, 1 J P–Rh = 91 Hz); 66.2 (d, 1 J P–Rh = 88 Hz, weak signal); 65.3 ((d, 1 J P–Rh = 90 Hz); 62.8 (J 195Pt–31P = 2807 Hz). ICP-OES: Zr/Pt/Rh/Co ratio of 6:1.38:0.5:0.05.

Reaction of <sup>t</sup>Bu<sub>4</sub>(L) with [Rh­(nbd)­Cl]<sub>2</sub>

A solution of [Rh­(nbd)­Cl]2 (2.7 mg, 0.006 mmol) in DMSO (0.2 mL) was added to a solution of tBu4(L) (10 mg, 0.011 mmol) in DMSO (0.4 mL). An immediate color change to bright yellow was observed, and 31P­{1H} NMR showed the formation of a single species giving rise to a major resonance at 79.8 ppm (d, 2P, 1 J P–Rh = 154.3 Hz) within 2 h.

cln_elements.content: TGA analysis of 1-CoCl3 shows a ∼53% mass loss up to 200 °C, consistent with the loss of guest solvent molecules from the porous framework (Figure S18). However, N2 adsorption isotherms (77 K) measured for a sample of 1-CoCl3(MeOH) desolvated by heating under reduced pressure (10–4 Torr, 100 °C) showed low N2 uptake and gave a calculated Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area of 366 m2 g–1 (Figure S19). X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) analysis of the desolvated samples revealed nearly complete loss of crystallinity, and attempts to activate 1-CoCl3 prior to solvent exchange or employ milder activation conditions to 1-CoCl3(MeOH) gave similar results. Despite its apparent structural collapse upon desolvation, 1-CoCl3(MeOH) retains guest accessible porosity when suspended in organic solvents as evidenced by its amenability to PSME (vide infra).
